titlestmt.titleproper: The Arts, Education and Americans Panel records
A Guide to the Arts, Education and Americans Panel records FA082
titlestmt.author: James E. Cyphers

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-10-01 04:07:09 UTC.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.unittitle: The Arts, Education and Americans Panel records

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The AEAP has title, copyright, and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them. Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish archival material from the collection.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The American Council for the Arts in Education (hereafter ACAE) was incorporated as a non-profit organization under the laws of the State of Ohio on January 31, 1972. It was the successor organization to the National Council for the Arts in Education (hereafter NCAIE), which had been founded in 1958. Neither the ACAE nor its parent organization were grant-making institutions; both organizations were primarily engaged in study activities intended to promote the arts as an integral part of the general school curriculum.

At its inception, the ACAE inherited the Arts/Worth Program from the NCAIE. This program received its impetus from the August 1969 Wingspread Conference and was designed "to alter American opinion about the place of the arts in the educational process." Under the direction of Alan Sapp and Joseph C. Sloane, the Arts/Worth Program engaged in a number of promotional and survey activities until financial pressures brought about its demise in 1974.

In 1974, Norris Houghton became president of the ACAE. Under his leadership, the organization tapped new sources of funding and designed its last major project: the Arts, Education and Americans Panel. The Panel was headed by David Rockefeller, Jr., and consisted of leading figures in the fields of government, the performing arts, business, and education. Its principal function was to determine the status of the arts in American education through intensive surveys and research, thereby formulating comprehensive proposals for the integration of the arts with all aspects of school curricula. The panel issued its final report, entitled "Coming to Our Senses," in May 1977.
Upon the release of this report, Arts, Education and Americans, Inc. was incorporated on May 24, 1977, as a separate non-profit corporation to carry on the work started by the Panel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The records of the ACAE as received by the Rockefeller Archive Center are incomplete. Activities prior to 1974, including the Arts/Worth Program, are not intended to be documented in this collection. The records focus sharply upon the activities of the Arts, Education and Americans Panel, the preparation and issuance of its report, "Coming to Our Senses," and supporting research. Correspondence after 1977 deals almost exclusively with the distribution of the Panel report.

Included in the records of the AEAP are reports, correspondence, memoranda, research papers, transcripts of meetings or conferences, financial records and clippings. Users of this collection are advised that Series 4, the files of Norris Houghton (president of the ACAE, 1974-1976) may present the fullest and most accessible overview of the ACAE policies and activities during the period covered therein, as the organization did not issue annual reports. This collection is comprised of manuscript boxes, books, photographs, slides, audio tape recordings, videotapes, charts, and film.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: See also the JDR 3rd Fund records.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The papers of The Arts, Education and Americans Panel of the American Council for the Arts in Education were deposited in the Rockefeller Archive Center on January 30, 1981.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The records of the Panel are divided into six series:
Series 1 - General Records Series 2 - Arts, Education and Americans Panel (AEA) Series 3 - Panel Report Series 4 - Norris Houghton Files Series 5 - Financial Records Series 1041 - Photographs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence regarding the Arts/Worth Program, background materials, and member organizations sponsoring the ACAE.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of correspondence, reports, records of interviews, meetings and conferences, research papers and questionnaires, and staff records.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is divided into five subseries:
Subseries A - Correspondence: Speakers and Consultants

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This subseries is arranged alphabetically, followed by a folder of form letters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes records of interviews and visits to model school art programs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries chiefly consists of records of insurance payments and publisher's bills.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes background materials on panel members and records of meetings and conferences.

did.unittitle: Meeting - Planning - Background and Opening/Closing Remarks
Meeting - Planning - Correspondence and Preparatory Material
Meeting - Background Information on Community Programs
Meeting - Conference - Materials for Panel Members

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of background material on staff members, records of meetings, research papers, questionnaires and responses, and statistics drawn up by the research staff for use of the panel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes a copy of the report, "Coming to Our Senses," followed by all drafts and revisions made in its preparation. This is followed by a file of correspondence, reports, distribution records, mailing lists, and other material related to the preparation of this report.

did.unittitle: Distribution List - People and Programs Mentioned in Report

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes correspondence, reports, records of meetings, and memoranda collected by Norris Houghton, president of the ACAE from 1974 to 1976.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is divided into two subseries:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes both American Council for the Arts in Education (ACAE) and National Council for the Arts in Education (NCAIE) materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of audits, check stubs, correspondence, petty cash slips, receipts, and tax records.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is arranged alphabetically by subject (e.g. tax records, loans, staff expenses) or by document type (e.g. audit, receipts).

physdesc.extent: 1 record storage box, and 1 letter document box

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The Rockefeller Archive Center recognizes that our audiovisual materials may contain problematic language and/or content.

The films, videos, and/or sound in this collection have not been altered in any way. All titles and/or content are illustrative of the creator's original vision. As such, this audiovisual collection may contain discriminatory visual and/or aural content that is representative of racial, gendered, or ableist biases.

Accompanying description, most often with creator or donor-generated language and terminology, has to this point been retained and maintained "as received" by RAC with minimal archivist intervention or augmentation.
We acknowledge these problems and aim to cultivate inclusive representation and equity by reconsidering and enhancing our description of this audiovisual material with current sensibilities.
